div.head: Virginia State Election--Political Revolution
div.summary: Sees a state and national political revolution that will culminate in the 1860 Presidential election. Traces political conflicts of 1850s. Fears that a new Presidential party is emerging.

div.head: The License Case
div.summary: Publication of Attorney General's opinion in a case involving Harman and Snapp, Staunton liquor distillers, and their employee Abney, charged with selling liquor without a license. Finds in Abney's favor.

div.head: The Candidates For Governor at Harrisonburg and Staunton
div.summary: Covers Letcher's and Goggin's meetings at Harrisonburg and Staunton on March 9 and 10.

div.head: Candidates for Legislature
div.summary: Calls for unity between Whigs and Americans versus the Democrats in the election.

div.head: For The Spectator; To The Whigs and Americans of Augusta
div.summary: Rallying cry for Whigs and Americans. Call for unity.

div.head: Opposition Electors and Canvassmen
div.summary: Article lists electors and canvassmen for all districts. List above includes only Augusta names: 9th Congressional-A. H. H. Stuart; 36th Senatorial-Robert L. Doyle; canvassers-J. Marshall McCue; J. M. Hangar; Bolivar Christian; N. Massie; George W. Imboden; Powell Harrison

div.head: Virginia To Wit

Wayt Bell; Thornton Berry; Henry Harrison; William M. Tate; George J. Armistrout*; District No. 1: William W. Donaghe; John Trimble; Albert J. Garber; Judson McCoy; William H. Shanker; E.M. Crawford*; Churchville: James Wilson; Bailey Dunlap; Henry Sterrett; John M. Huff; Harvey Bare; R. P. Eubanks*; Swoope's Depot: Samuel H. Bell; Washington Swoope, Sr; George Shuey; Jacob Baylor; A. Martin; Dr. John McCheney; James Berry; Thomas Steele; A. S. Turk*; Deerfield: William Guy; William W. Montgomery; Renix Hodges; J. Mann; Dr. McCutcheon; Edwin Montgomery. List will be published for three weeks.

div.head: List of Delinquent Tax-Payers

page.pageNote: All of the articles in columns 1-3 relate to the elections, some from Augusta, some from other counties.

div.excerpt: "On Sunday last thirty-seven were admitted to church membership, at least one half of whom were over thirty years of age, heads of families and leading citizens of that community."

transcript.p: The revival in the Presbyserian [sic] Church of Waynesboro, of which we made mention a month ago, still continues in interest and accessions. On Sunday last thirty-seven were admitted to church membership, at least one-half of whom were over thirty years of age,heads of families and leading citizens of that community. As many more, it is expected, will unite themselves with the church at the next Lord's Supper. Among the colored population of the village, similar evidence of the influence of the spirit are manifest.

div.summary: The Presbyterian church revival in Waynesboro has achieved great success amongst both the white and black populations.

div.head: Married
div.summary: All of Augusta, married on March 10.
